text:
@choldgraf @_msw_ @matteocollina Here at Anaconda, @teoliphant and I have made plenty of mistakes over the years, but only in extreme circumstances have we ever told employees they must toe some party line.
Our folks go out and mingle and interact with the community as themselves. I think that builds trust.
name: Peter Wang

text:
@choldgraf @_msw_ @matteocollina The dev community are more cynical and savvy than typical B2C consumer. Most of them work for BigCo's anyways, so they know precisely how the marketing sausage is made.

One thing I've noticed is that corporate entities earn trust when they let their employees be themselves.
name: Peter Wang

text: @choldgraf @_msw_ @matteocollina None of these generally compute in a CFO's spreadsheet. Ergo, most C-corps can't really earn trust. They can spend a bunch of money to "polish the brand", but IMO that works against them, when what's required is that they humanize the brand of the business.
name: Peter Wang

text: @pwang @choldgraf @_msw_ @matteocollina Thanks for the tag..definitely something I am interested in.  Companies sometimes struggle to work well with community driven open source software.  It can be better to offer development grants rather than hiring people away from the community — and also fund community orgs.
name: Travis Oliphant

text: @pwang @choldgraf @_msw_ @matteocollina If you do hire people give them at least half time to work on OSS (where they are already active) and *then* also donate to community organizations like @NumFOCUS to ensure their contributions can be integrated with others and maintain community-driven status.
name: Travis Oliphant

text: @_msw_ @pwang @choldgraf @matteocollina @NumFOCUS This is really interesting.  Congratulations on the success.  Is there a community organization that you could spend some small percentage of the cost of the OSS engineers you pay for to strengthen the community as well?  This is a new addition we have been trying.
name: Travis Oliphant

text:
@glyph @pganssle At the end of the day, if no one pays, then our ledger would be a simple measure of the total shortfall of desired compensation across all devs & projects.
It's like measuring carbon footprint - it's a quantification of how economically unsustainable our OSS ecosystem is.

text:
@giffmana But I doubt that making the stride equal to the kernel size is an essential (or even useful) characteristic of your architecture.
You could probably make the stride, say 12x12 instead of 16x16, and get similar (if not better) perf with marginal cost increase.
name: Yann LeCun

text:
@giffmana Yes, a uniform diagonal operator (i.e. a simple scaling) is a degenerate limit case of conv. 
Though we are talking about multiple conv where the objects being conv'ed are vectors, and the operation on them is multiplication by a matrix. The same shared matrix for all sites.
name: Yann LeCun

text:
@apachaves @rasbt @JFPuget @jeremyphoward 3/2 :) To moderate the importance of cross-validation, note that it evaluates fitting procedures and not fitted models.

I do find it interesting to look the variability across folds to check for catastrophic failures and prefer procedures without catastrophic failures.
name: Gael Varoquaux

text:
@apachaves @rasbt @JFPuget @jeremyphoward The logic behind using most complex and expensive models is because prior work established that they work best. But weak evaluation adds no information to this prior work and gives little guarantees that they are best for the application at hand. 
2/2
name: Gael Varoquaux

text: I just realized it's in the afternoon and my ideas aren't as coherent as in the mornings.  So I'll end here and mull this over while I sleep.

text: Because they are explicitly encoded, we need libraries and frameworks so that they can be easily created.  This is kind of missing today in that it's kind of like rocket science to construct the necessary smart contracts for a complex service.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text: For many, this sounds strange that we are discussing something that is so obviously implemented in the real world.  But in the crypto world, these things have to be explicitly encoded.

text: So as an example, when I subscribe to a network service like Netflix,  it does not matter how much or how few videos I consume a month.  I pay a fixed price. This works for consumers over a pay-per-view model.  Different services lend to different payment plans.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text: What cryptocurrencies aren't able to provide are flexible payment and compensation schemes.  Payment and compensation is calculated only at that time of a transaction and not on a wholesale or deferred basis. Mechanisms should be invented to allow this flexibility.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text: So there are two kinds of participants,  those who participate in the realm of more mature services that can be repeated and those who compete in newer more innovative but bespoke solutions.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text:

text: RT @mathcolorstrees:Got a story for you. Years ago when I was a new PhD grad working at Twitter, there was a director of product who had strong ideas about how to solve the abuse and harassment problem on Twitter.
name: Emily Robinson

text: RT @EmilyGorcenski:An experience every data scientist either has had or will have is working for a product manager who has absolutely no concept of data but who insists their conclusions must be correct and it’s the fault of the data scientists for not being smart enough to prove them.
name: Emily Robinson

text: RT @hmason:I think every data scientist has a story about a time when someone from product or business with relative power demanded they find a specific pre-determined answer in the data. Data scientists generally push back. How this goes depends on the quality of the org and leadership.
name: Emily Robinson

RT @eyspahn:A few missing considerations:

- Can the problem be solved easier, without ML?
- Is this a good use case for ML, or might there be ethical issues (e.g. auto-firing someone)?
- Do you have sufficient data?
- How explainable do decisions need to be?

text:
@averyjjackson It’s tough because most senior data/ML folks still don’t see it as a marker of capability to handle a task. Unique projects still hold more weight unless the role asks for certain certs. 

They can be good for standing out, but you can’t opt out of coding interviews w/ a cert.
name: Ayodele | Data Science Career Coach

text: RT @iamKierraD:Data Analysis requires some level of coding language knowledge, you need SQL in some capacity. You'd have a better chance with data governance since some positions don't require you to be AS hands on with reporting tools/platforms. Either way, you should know sql basics.
name: Ayodele | Data Science Career Coach

text:
Had a great convo about why Black Data Scientists don’t just stick to data science. 

I’m just as likely to be adversely impacted by shitty tech as Black ppl who don’t work in tech. I don’t get to ignore that these tools encode lies about millions of Black ppl. This piece = 💎
name: Ayodele | Data Science Career Coach

text: One of the things I hate about ML is that we always talk about using it to fix "business" problems when in reality many businesses are trying to solve societal problems with technology.
name: Ayodele | Data Science Career Coach

text:
Local gov: "HELP! It's taking too long to review unemployment/healthcare benefits w/ the ppl we have on staff. Can you help us?"

TechCo: *automates it & it turns out biased against poor, Black communities* 

Better solution: Hire more anti-racist/equity-driven human reviewers
name: Ayodele | Data Science Career Coach

text: @joranelias Oh, totally! Like, all the gun checks in the airport feel almost apologetic.
name: Mara Averick

text:
Knowledge Vs Experience 

> Knowledge emphasizes collecting and connecting existing ideas
> Experience stresses practice, or the application of knowledge over a prolonged period of time
> After experience, comes creativity... https://t.co/0PwFpCKxV3
name: Pascal Bornet

text: 27 Milestones In The #History Of #QuantumComputing via @forbes https://t.co/J4X2f5Lsr1 #QuantumTechnology
name: Gil Press

text: politely asking them to take a look at a blog post you wrote up about a project, or your resume. (Note that asking them to do something like this for you shouldn't be your first interaction, build a rapport via engaging with them in other ways first.)
name: Data Science Renee

text: After you've been following people in the data science sub-group that you're interested in moving towards, you should start to get a sense of the terminology, the questions they ask of their data, the types of data products they build.
name: Data Science Renee

text: You might also interact and build connections that you can lean on to get feedback, letting them know that you have been following their career and appreciate the guidance you get from their social media shares,
name: Data Science Renee

text: You might tweet them some of your industry/career questions, to get an answer from someone in the sub-field you're now looking closer at.
name: Data Science Renee

text: Maybe ask if there are recordings of them presenting anything, or if they have any resources to recommend with advice for getting into the specific field they're in.
name: Data Science Renee

text: But with this approach, you're mostly learning by watching what they do, seeing who they talk to, what they value, professionally. If they share an article and say it resonates with them, you can guess that it's relevant to their career experiences or the type of work they do.
name: Data Science Renee

text: You get the idea - "mentor yourself" by finding role models that are more specific than "shares data science stuff" and dig into an industry, a company, or a type of machine learning to get details from someone who does that kind of work.
name: Data Science Renee

text: I hope this is helpful! Feel free to ask questions!
name: Data Science Renee

text: Also what not to do, because this makes it hard for someone to help you and probably won't get you actually helpful responses: Find a data science "personality" and ask them something very general like "Can you tell me how to learn data science?"
name: Data Science Renee

text: RT @hadleywickham:We're exploring ways to automatically add some basic alt text to ggplot2 plots (which would eventually automatically flow in to Rmds). This will obviously be inferior to manually written text, but should hopefully be substantially better than nothing. What should it include?
name: Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel

text: That is such a broad question that they can't effectively answer without knowing more about your background, your interests, what kind of data science you mean, etc. So do the initial legwork of finding out about different fields/applications, do some of this self-mentoring,
name: Data Science Renee

text: If you're brand new, start with the video I posted at the top of this thread, hopefully it will give you some ideas of where to start.
name: Data Science Renee

text:
or find an already-built curriculum online (either a series of short courses, or a syllabus from a college data science course) and use that to find starter topics to dive into.

Here's one: https://t.co/4IcsVTe7XZ
name: Data Science Renee

text: But look at those resources as a starting point to find areas to dive into deeper, not as a checklist. You're figuring out the general area so you can better navigate it. You don't have to learn everything on these catch-all lists in order to be considered a data scientist!
name: Data Science Renee

text:
RT @susansivek:Coming up in just 10 minutes at #AlteryxInspire! 

@alteryx #DataScience
name: Data Science Renee

text: @rcaneuro Great, so glad to hear it!
name: Data Science Renee

text: I know a lot of you weren't able to watch it live, but I'm happy to answer Qs anytime - here it is on YouTube, and if you want audio-only to listen to in your favorite podcast player, there's a link earlier in the thread to the Data Science Mixer podcast feed.
name: Data Science Renee

text: and then once you've found something more specific that interests you, your questions will be more specific and directed at the right people who can actually give you helpful responses.
name: Data Science Renee

text:
3. Find a relevant dataset (an image dataset if you're learning about computer vision, a health dataset if you're looking to get into the health industry, etc) and use it for learning some of those skills you found you had gaps in.

I always recommend project-based learning.
name: Data Science Renee

name: Data Science Renee

text: - Find people on twitter who are doing things that are interesting to you. Read through their tweets, blog posts, etc to learn more about what they do and what kinds of skills are involved. See if you can find interviews they or someone like them did on a podcast or article.
name: Data Science Renee

text: So if you're totally unfamiliar, find some resources to orient yourself to the various types of data science and pick a direction to start going. Since we're on twitter, I'll add steps I'd do (and have done) here on twitter for this phase.
name: Data Science Renee

text:
RT @abigailgeiger:Thread: A look at the ongoing protests in Colombia through data visualization. Shoutout to @InvisiblesMuros for his great coverage. 
👇
name: Fernando Pérez

text:
- Things I would say help define a type of data scientist
-- Industry (for example, biotech)
-- What they're building
-- Role (solo, on a team, leading a team, etc)
-- "stack" (python, Tableau, etc)
name: Data Science Renee

text:
The types of skills I need to do this are very different than, say, a data scientist working on self-driving car navigation.

If I wanted to switch to the self-driving car industry/computer vision, I would have to do many of the things in this thread to figure out what to learn.
name: Data Science Renee

text: Find a few different types of data scientists on social media and read up to figure out what "type" of data scientist they are, and determine if that's the direction you want to take your career.
name: Data Science Renee

text: There's no "wrong" choice here, you have to start somewhere, and it's rare that a skill you learn would be wasted. Even if you switch tech stacks or industries later, a lot of what you learn pursuing one will be helpful/transferable to another when you're beyond beginner.
name: Data Science Renee

text:
RT @garrytan:I want @Initialized to be a franchise venture capital firm— a unicorn every year, a decacorn every few. 

The limiting reagent is not ideas or great founders. The limiting reagent is actually good investors who won’t eff up companies.

https://t.co/F4HUKJ6eVk
name: Peter Wang

text:
2. Figure out where you're at in relation to this desired type of data science you want to learn more about.

Are there people working in this type of job with your level of formal education? What kinds of technical skills would you need to learn to do the work they're doing?
name: Data Science Renee

text: For example, I'm a data scientist who works with data collected by universities. It is tabular data, and most of the models I build are either binary classifiers or time series models.
name: Data Science Renee

text: Look up job postings in the companies that the "role models" you found are working in. Do they sound like the kind of thing you want to do? What's the delta between where you are now and a job posting you find exciting, or that looks like a step in the right direction?
name: Data Science Renee

text: (I'll come back and add more here later)
name: Data Science Renee

text:
I'll just jot down ideas as they come to mind. Feel free to ask Qs, and I'll come back and answer them later.

This will probably be very similar in theme to my pydata talk from 2016
https://t.co/qZ8vXyjZWR

text: RT @EricRWeinstein:No. We should acknowledge that it was a bunch of scientists who refused to shut up and who put their reputations on line to be able to say “We refuse to take the Lab hypothesis off the table because we don’t do that in science...you transparent, bullying, authoritarian putzes.”
name: Peter Wang

text: 1. If you're just entering data science, you need to know that "data science" isn't one thing. There are a variety of career paths and types of machine learning and each requires slightly (or sometimes very) different skills, etc.
name: Data Science Renee

text:
Are there related jobs you can do on the way to that job? Data Analyst? Data Engineer? etc

How well do you know the domain? Are there meetups or conferences you can attend to learn what people in the field are talking about, what kinds of questions they're answering with data?
name: Data Science Renee

text: It is indeed odd that after 100 years, we still do not have good models of abduction as if it was an entirely alien idea.  But it is right there before our very eyes.  The systematic thought process that we call science is an abductive process.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text: 3 Tools to Help Leaders Steady Their Teams During a Transition https://t.co/ynyOGjrd9D #leadership https://t.co/yqPBU0EYVj
name: Tamara McCleary

text: Intuition or amortized inference is an emergent property of an evolutionary process. Furthermore, reasoning is an emergent property of an intuitive process.  In fact, 100 years ago, C.S. Peirce sketched out the evolution of inference: intuition->deduction->abduction.
name: Carlos E. Perez

text: An 'intuitive understanding' is driven by the conceptual model of reality that we have adopted.  So the Greek's might explain a flood as Poseidon being angry.  This reasoning will be less accurate than the reasoning of someone trained in meteorology.
name: Carlos E. Perez

RT @AgencyCecil:Today I tried to fight the power and free myself from Google Analytics. 👊🏿⛓️

text: @JestDempsey The amount I change spark plugs is excessive, but if you have a vehicle they're accessible on it's cheap, easy and doesn't hurt. If the plugs aren't accessible then I do them once a year in the fall. I do everything myself, so cost is minimal for me and it's all fast.
name: Colin McGuire

text: @JestDempsey I run full synthetic with additives and still do a full oil, lube, filter, air filters change and clean the fuel injectors every 7,000. Every 6mos or so I toss in new NGK plugs & depending on the vehicle clean the O2 sensor. Those little things keep a vehicle running perfectly.
name: Colin McGuire

text:
New Client: "How's your schedule to do an onsite week?"

text:
RT @EmilyGorcenski:Some of the problems I have with dashboards:

- they’re hard to version control
- they’re hard to test
- they let you hide code
- that hidden code becomes de facto business logic
- they are a terminator in an automation chain
name: Pete Skomoroch

text: RT @EmilyGorcenski:To solve the dashboard problem, we have to recognize them as breaking a chain of automation, and try to figure out how to better tie together that automation. You can still have dashboards for informative purposes! But let’s focus on what happens to the right of the dashboard.
name: Pete Skomoroch

text:
RT @EmilyGorcenski:Dashboards enable managers to look at data and make decisions. There are a lot of assumptions here:

- that sufficient context is presented with the data
- that the data are correct
- that the transformation logic is correct
- that the data are complete
name: Pete Skomoroch

text: RT @EmilyGorcenski:Dashboards represent an endpoint in an automated workflow. Which means they create an open-loop system. It’s very hard to link the dashboard that was observed to the decisions, and therefore the effect of those decisions, taken based on what was observed.
name: Pete Skomoroch
